articles.headline: Poland’s Heartland Would Rather Keep E.U. Money Than Break With Bloc
articles.snippet: Despite the flame-throwing rhetoric of their leaders, conservative supporters of Poland’s ruling party are dependent on millions of euros in aid, and don’t want to risk it.
articles.abstract: Despite the flame-throwing rhetoric of their leaders, conservative supporters of Poland’s ruling party are dependent on millions of euros in aid, and don’t want to risk it.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOBYLIN-BORZYMY, Poland — The twin steeples of Saint Stanislaus, a hulking, red-brick Catholic church, are visible for miles across the corn fields and cow pastures of this conservative area of eastern Poland, a bastion of support for the country’s nationalist governing party.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Covid Shots for Children 5 to 11
articles.snippet: Covid-19 was “the eighth-highest killer of kids in this age group over the past year,” said a C.D.C. official in favor of broader authorization.
articles.abstract: Covid-19 was “the eighth-highest killer of kids in this age group over the past year,” said a C.D.C. official in favor of broader authorization.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An expert committee advising the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday recommended that regulators authorize Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine for 5- to 11-year-olds, bringing about 28 million children a major step closer to becoming eligible for shots.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Democrats Hammer Out Novel Plan to Tax Billionaires and Corporate Giants
articles.snippet: New proposals would fund social and climate programs by tapping billionaires’ unrealized gains and by ensuring that the biggest companies cannot avoid income taxes altogether.
articles.abstract: New proposals would fund social and climate programs by tapping billionaires’ unrealized gains and by ensuring that the biggest companies cannot avoid income taxes altogether.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats rushed on Tuesday to nail down the details of a groundbreaking tax on billionaires’ wealth, part of an elaborate menu of tax increases to finance a significantly scaled-back bill that would strengthen the social safety net and address climate change.

articles.headline: Anonymity No More? Age Checks Come to the Web.
articles.snippet: To protect children online, more companies and governments are forcing users to prove how old they are.
articles.abstract: To protect children online, more companies and governments are forcing users to prove how old they are.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard Errington clicked to stream a science-fiction film from his home in Britain last month when YouTube carded him.

articles.headline: Higher Food Prices Hit the Poor and Those Who Help Them
articles.snippet: Many households are being forced to adjust their shopping lists or seek assistance. But food banks, too, are feeling the pinch.
articles.abstract: Many households are being forced to adjust their shopping lists or seek assistance. But food banks, too, are feeling the pinch.
articles.lead_paragraph: With food prices surging, many Americans have found their household budgets upended, forcing difficult choices at the supermarket and putting new demands on programs intended to help.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Coral Murphy Marcos

articles.headline: Gangs Rule Much of Haiti. For Many, It Means No Fuel, No Power, No Food.
articles.snippet: A country in crisis is facing a severe fuel shortage that is pushing it to the brink of collapse.
articles.abstract: A country in crisis is facing a severe fuel shortage that is pushing it to the brink of collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Gangs blocking Haiti’s ports, choking off fuel shipments. Hospitals on the verge of shutting down as generators run dry, risking the lives of hundreds of children. Cellphone towers going without power, leaving swaths of the country isolated. And an acute hunger crisis growing more severe each day.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Maria Abi-Habib

articles.headline: He Unleashed a California Massacre. Should This School Be Named for Him?
articles.snippet: The founder of the Hastings College of the Law masterminded the killings of hundreds of Native Americans. The school, tribal members and alumni disagree about what should be done now.
articles.abstract: The founder of the Hastings College of the Law masterminded the killings of hundreds of Native Americans. The school, tribal members and alumni disagree about what should be done now.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Pastries and Persuasion: How a Global Tax Deal Got Done
articles.snippet: Over Zoom calls from basements and a breakfast in Brussels, faltering negotiations to remake the world’s tax architecture were revived.
articles.abstract: Over Zoom calls from basements and a breakfast in Brussels, faltering negotiations to remake the world’s tax architecture were revived.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over a two-hour breakfast of tea and pastries at the Hotel Amigo in Brussels in July, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen tried to persuade Paschal Donohoe, the Irish finance minister, to abandon Ireland’s rock bottom corporate tax rate and join the global deal the Biden administration was racing to clinch.

articles.headline: China’s Weapon Tests Close to a ‘Sputnik Moment,’ U.S. General Says
articles.snippet: Gen. Mark A. Milley said China’s testing of a hypersonic missile “has all of our attention.”
articles.abstract: Gen. Mark A. Milley said China’s testing of a hypersonic missile “has all of our attention.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — China’s testing of a hypersonic missile designed to evade American nuclear defenses was “very close” to a “Sputnik moment” for the United States, Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Wednesday in the first official confirmation of how Beijing’s demonstration of its weapon capabilities had taken American officials by surprise.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
